newsitem.title: USA: Citrix says Microsoft small part of growth.
newsitem.headline: Citrix says Microsoft small part of growth.

text.p: Citric Systems Corp's record second quarter revenues and earnings were the result of strong traditional business practices, not an abberation caused by a recent deal with Microsoft Corp, Citrix said Tuesday.
"The business that you see from the quarter was our basic channel business, our bread and butter business," said Edward Iacobucci, chairman and chief technology officer of Citric, in an interview.

On Monday, the software maker said its second quarter earnings per share rose to $0.29, up from $0.14 a year ago. Revenues jumped to $24.5 million compared to $9.8 million in the same period last year.
In May, Citrix signed a licensing deal with Microsoft Corp, that will bring in to Citrix an initial $75 million in fees and up to $100 million in royalties.
James Felcyn, Citrix's chief financial officer, said that the income from the deal is pro-rated and that only about 10 percent of the revenue recorded in the second quarter came from Microsoft.
"The Microsoft component, pro-rated in, was about $2.1 million," he said, adding that virtually all of the company's growth in the period was from sales of its packaged software.

Citrix writes software that lets an old PC or an outdated terminal -- a type of computer that gets its computing power from a corporate network -- run programs written for Microsoft's Windows. The deal involves technology which would let several terminal using Windows NT use a single server for running common business software.
The two companies will also co-market future products.
Citrix has also recently announced a licensing agreement with Amdahl Corp and a marketing pact with 3Com Corp .

While neither Citrix executive would make projections about future earnings, Iacobucci said he is "cautiously optimistic," and notes that the company's current business model should produce stable growth.

"It's strong steady growth," he said. "It (the software) is a solution that is needed, regardless of whatever is on the horizon, and I think with (the deal with) Microsoft it's just taking away some concerns that were on the horizon."
Shares of Citrix fell 2-5/8 to 52-5/8 in active trade on Tuesday.
